comments.commentBody: Ah yes, there is NachoHomey, blasting ND. Let me see, he lives in the bastion of liberal waste, in a state with what percent of unemployment? How broke is your state? How high is your crime rate? Have you ever been to ND? Probably not, it's just easier for so called "open minded" liberal to berate something/somewhere/someone than it is to understand the facts. By the way, ND is well on it's way to becoming a leading producer of wind energy, on top of being a large producer of oil and hydroelectric energy. Then one could get into the amount of food produced in that state. What more essential products are there in life than food and energy? Visit ND sometime, I have. You may be surprised that they really don't live in the 50s, but then for someone with your "intellect", I'm sure you can't fathom how that could be since they vote conservative.

"I guess Obama is finally admitting private sector is more efficient than public sector. Took him a long time to realize that obvious fact." -Tealoban mantra

This would almost make half-witted sense except for the fact the US ranks #20 against public educations systems in socialist democracies across the world. But the good news is we pay an additional 40% per capita for that ranking.

From the Tealobans capacity for logic, America can see that public education has indeed gone astray. Typically due to litigation by Tealoban parents that has forced the schools (part of the "evil government" to teach the Tealoban's minimes that science is merely just another political opinion.

On September 2, 2009, President Obama and other members of his administration visited various schools to discuss the importance of an education. His message - broadcast to schools that day throughout our nation - was to encourage students to maximize their educational opportunities.

What happened last year? Republicans and their extreme right-wing, using their TV and radio mouthpieces, threatened to boycott the president’s speech by having their children opt out from attending school that day, afraid that Obama would be advancing his personal agenda and - in their words - “cult of personality.”

President Obama’s speech was what every parent, teacher and role model seeks to instill in youngsters: stay in school, take advantage of your educational opportunities and work hard. Boy, how subversive must that idea and wish seem to Republicans and conservatives.

I would have been thrilled as a school child to have the president of the United States – Republican or Democrat – take time out of his busy schedule to speak directly to me and my classmates. Republicans and conservatives chose, however, to politicize the president’s talk to students a year ago.

Now, a year later, they still criticize the president for wanting what any parent wants for his/her children: the best education possible. Simply unbelievable!

George Bush got a five-year honeymoon following 9/11; Republicans portrayed any questioning of their guy tantamount to lack of patriotism -- and it was very clever of them to portray Obama within three months of his election as the man who'd taken us down the drain.  You do have to give them credit for successful spin, which ignores Bush's failure to veto anything (including big government spending) until the fifth year of his administration, when, alas, some Democrats were elected and he could show the power of his veto.  Repubs have the Dems beat when it comes to expressing rage:  where was the rage when we overlooked Afghanistan as the greater danger and unnecessarily invaded Iraq (but most Dems didn't want to appear unpatriotic)?  Even G.H.W. Bush said (in his book, The World Transformed) that he didn't invade Iraq because "we'd have to occupy an openly hostile country" -- but then G. Bush has said he has his "mama's mouth" and his "daddy's eyes." One former Republican to whom I've spoken in CA says the nation will never recover from G. Bush -- but that's overly pessimistic -- give it maybe 30 years.
Leave it to a Republican to even try and raise the dead for support.

Romulus Rex is right. As long as we allow Republicans to appeal to people who have very little with their jargon about Democrats wanting to raise taxes, our American way of life with all the benefits we have cherished for decades such as Medicare, Social Security and better health care, we stand to lose everything. As Democrats, we must fight by telling middle income Americans the truth- that Republicans, especially the tea party, are only out for the wealthy. I don't know about anyone else on this thread, but I am 56 years old, disabled and must have both my medicare and social security benefits. Without Medicare, I will die because I would not be able to afford my medication. I hope nobody is even thinking about telling my I am using their tax dollars.... I worked very hard until becoming disabled and contrary to popular belief, your Social Security payments are a percentage of what you earned. Nobody pays for another's Social Security benefit. Medicare part A is paid with tax dollars you have paid into the system, but part B and Part D come out of your own pocket. The bottom line is that Republicans do not respect human life.

I am amazed when I hear people talk about death panels because of an ignorant statement by Sarah Palin. If she or anyone of her followers would just read the Medicare handbook, they would know that the end of life conversation between doctors and patients is already being paid for by Medicare for several years now. There is no such thing as a death panel unless, of course, Amercans cannot have access to reaslonable priced, good quality health care; this would be a death panel with only Republicans on it.

To all those who feel that Obama "doesn't get it," here's another piece of the answer - he's attempting incremental change to lessen the aftershocks. There is so much to be done, that doing it all at once would be devastating; doing it piece by piece, undoing nearly 30 years of Republican "trickle down" disaster, is the best way to proceed. Thank you, President Obama, for this help to small business owners like me!

It is comforting to know that the Progs are stunned by the depth of anger across the country at the tin eared, arrogant, supercillious dem congress and Obama administration. Also interesting that their superior intellect quickly is able to identify those not in agreement with their specious arguments as "trolls" and "troglodytes" and "twits". Terrible thing when the great unwashed uneducated masses disappoint and reject their pablum.

But just like the apologist in chief, they just don't get it. Truly a case where the nut doesn't fall far from the tree.

Can you imagine the daily disruption with Secret Service had the president sent his daughters to a  D.C. public school? All we'd hear is the right wing screaming about the money spent to keep them safe (because I bet security would be a little bit different than when Amy Carter was in school). A private school with a smaller student body is better equipped to handle the necessary security.

So Caroline,
Since Bush was bad, Obama has to be worse. Bush signed a prescription bill with some semblance of market discipline, Obama has to sign a bill that does away with such niceties. Most tea party sympathizers were against Bush's spending too but Obama has quadrupled down on those lofty numbers and that is why there is such an outrage now.
Grayson needs some hygiene help.  He always looks like he is covered in grease.  Someone needs to show him how to tuck in his shirt, and wipe the sweat from his face before appearing on camera
Yet another official fleeing Obama's sinking ship.

I'm one of the Republicans that _almost_ voted for President Obama. Although I felt my choices were between "Bad" and "Worse" in the 2008 election (and I never was sure which candidate was which), I was pleased when President Obama won

I had high hopes for the President. He seems intelligent. He seemed genuine is his desire to move past partisan politics and for an open, transparent, honest government. I gave him every benefit of the doubt. Eventually, however, his actions just didn't mesh with his promises.

Personally, I blame Speaker Pelosi for most of the rift with moderates and independents. Every word she mutters is poisoned with partisan rhetoric. It likely stems from spending too much time fighting in the trenches. Apparently, the President and I have diametrically opposed views on many issues. For me and my middle-class family, government consumes the largest block of our income and provides little in return. Our roads in the San Francisco Bay Area are among the nation's worst. The public schools are below average. Employers have left or are leaving for other states and countries, where taxes are lower and people still have a work ethic.

Unfortunately, the President's appeal is too late for me. Too much trust and hopefulness have been destroyed. He and the gross dysfunction by BOTH self-serving parties in Washington and Sacramento have "radicalized" this once moderate Republican. I now fully understand the purpose behind the checks and balances in the Constitution and why we need limits on government power. President Obama has strengthened my belief in empowering the individual, local control, and why true free-market solutions are the best path--free from the crony capitalism of government control.

I don't like everything that I hear from Tea Party candidates. However, I like their small government message far more than the big-government Progressive pabulum widely dispensed here in the failed state of California.
Mr. Emanuel will fit well in Chicago. I hope the people in Chicago realize that he is just another rat jumping from Obama's ship to what seems to him to be a better nest to fleece.

Mike, responding to your Sunday NY Times matchup preview of the Bears-Packers Game, I hope you're ready to reconsider your view that the Bears are a "mediocre team." Only team in the NFC that is 3-0. Medicore, I think not buddy. Please write a retraction.
The Military trains people to become killers.  What do they expect?  Is it the fault of the soldier or of the government for creating the means of death.....

bill hubbard

Somehow, I didn't get the intellectual content of your argument. Do you mean that my revulsion against this incident, my rejection of killing civilians for fun, makes you think I'm a poor US citizen? If so, what kind of country do you want to have?

My ancestors fought in the American Revolution, and for this country in every war since then. I don't think the "love it or leave it" nation you envision is at all what they had in mind.

Keep your airfare. Spend your money on a course in American history and civics. I live five miles from the Canadian border. If and when I decide to give up on the US, I'll walk.

#22 self-appointed marine lawyer clearly doesn't know much about blockades, international law, or the Middle East.

Yes blockades are legal, provided they don't contravene other laws such as the Geneva Convention. However the Fourth Geneva Convention explicitly bans a blockade intended to deprive the civilian population of civilian goods as an act of collective punishment. To quote: "No protected person may be punished for an offense he or she has not personally committed. Collective penalties and likewise all measures of intimidation or of terrorism are prohibited."

Israel's blockade enforced a list of banned items including chocolate, chewing gum, childrens' crayons, paper, noodles etc. and was clearly aimed at causing deprivation among the civilian population, including well-documented infant and maternal malnutrition and literally hundreds of unnecessary deaths due to denial of medical treatment.

Moreover, Israel's actions in Gaza include the deliberate destruction of civilian infrastructure, destroying hospitals, schools, power plants, sewage treatment plants, and even digging up and destroying gas pipes, all counter to the Geneva Convention's prohibition of "extensive destruction and appropriation of property not justified by military necessity and carried out unlawfully and wantonly".

And all of this violence against the civilian population is to aid Israel in carrying out its ultimate goal: to violate Article 49 of the Geneva Convention which states "The Occupying Power shall not transfer parts of its own civilian population into the territory it occupies." ie. no settlements.

Good luck to these brave people. Maybe they can teach Israelis real human and Jewish values. God knows a lot of them need a lesson.

Paladino's bully style is more like a dictatorship on the extreme right!! Wow! America is changing the classic centrist democracy for the leadership of new idealogists who do not believe in positive thinking anymore but very negative way to sea the USA. If we want to make more enemies worldwide, then we should start electing a new crop of dictators like Palin & Paladino. In adddition, like in Iran, religious thinking will be implemented as part of public administration. I don't want the democrats, the Federal and State governments looking into my wallet every time the republicans create a fiscal deficit or start a new war overseas. However, I don't want them to look into my soul either, trying to impose their belief  and personal style, like new "dictators" in our society. That scares me!! It seems that we are going back to the XV century in Europe, or to the Soviet Union in the XX century!! Watch your wallet and watch your soul!!

I certainly agree with those who argue that Paladino will be no friend of NYC. As a developer he will be no friend of tenants either. The reporter calls him a bully, but remember that Eliot Spitzer called himself a [expletive deleted] steamroller and look how that turned out. Both cheated on their wives, so that's a wash. And Spitzer's father is a developer too, only the Spitzers are downstaters and Paladino is an upstater.

It's the same old New York State political scene, downstate and cities vs. upstate and suburbs, and the election will be much closer than any of us would care to think. My guess is that those awful new ballot scanners will serve Paladino well as they jam and break and cause city Democrats to walk away from long lines at the polls without casting votes for Cuomo. I fear that Paladino voters, anti-incumbent and sharing their man's rage, will succeed in electing their candidate.

This is just not the Democrats' year, for a number of reasons. Since Cuomo is an incumbent and Paladino isn't, the rage guy just may make it into the governor's mansion in spite of himself.

Oh, how I wish NYC would just secede from the state and be done with it! We need our freedom. Let's get a divorce!
I don't believe much of what Paladino has to say due to his brash talk and history, however, Cuomo is not much better.  Albany is as corrupt.  Can we get someone to run for governor...anyone else?

Mark (from Tucson, AZ) read my mind!  I read this article, and thought, "Wow--and I thought Arizona had cornered the market on crazy, bigoted, right-wing nuts!"  I always thought New Yorkers were more refined and "sane".  (okay, okay...don't laugh!)  I shudder to think what the next 4 yrs. would be like if Paladino occupies your governor's office.  Put him in a room with Jan Brewer (our governor), and you'd have a couple of perfectly matched book-ends.

I am having a hard time getting past the affair with an "employee" and fathering a child. He thought so much of his wife that his son knew before her? Why are people willing to overlook this when they would not tolerate this behavior in other politician?

"And when an older man, the lone holdout blocking Mr. Paladino’s development of a megastore, refused to sell the house he had lived in for 50 years, Mr. Paladino filed plans to surround the man’s home with a sea of asphalt, which officials rejected."  So Tea Partiers, in the foregoing story, are you the guy who had lived in his house for 50 years and wanted to stay rather than get money, or are you a megadeveloper who would punish the little guy?
